_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Oxiteno USA, LLC (Oxiteno) owns and operates a chemical manufacturing facility located in Pasadena, Texas.  The facility is a batch chemical production plant that produces amphoteric surfactants, esters, and solutions for the agrochemical market.

  

The following information is intended to satisfy the requirements under 40 CFR ?68.155 regarding the Executive Summary of a United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Risk Management Plan (RMP).  In this facility, Oxiteno handles Ethylene oxide (CAS 75-21-8), Sulfur dioxide (CAS 7446-09-5), and Propylene oxide (CAS 75-56-9). Ethylene oxide and Propylene oxide are handled in volumes that exceed the threshold quantity as prescribed under Table 1 of 40 CFR ?68.130.  Sulfur dioxide is also handled at the facility but does not exceed the threshold quantity, however, it is included in the RMP voluntarily by Oxiteno.  Additionally, these processes are subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standards under 29 CFR 1910.119 and is under Code 325199 of the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS).  As such, the Program 3 Prevention Program is applicable.



1.1    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Ethylene oxide (EtO), Sulfur dioxide (SO2), and Propylene oxide (PO) are used as part of various processes at the facility.  The substances are stored in and unloaded from railcars, stored in tanks, and used in site reactors.  The same properties that makes EtO, SO2, and PO valuable to Oxiteno's production process also makes it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling the substance to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own personal health and welfare as well as those of its employees, and to reduce the threat to the nearby population.  It is Oxiteno's policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which EtO, SO2, and PO is hand

led, the safety devices inherent in the design of the facility, and the safe handling procedures that are used and the training provided to personnel.



Oxiteno's emergency response program is based upon Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Standards.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for the notification of the local emergency services and any affected neighbors in the vicinity of the site.  



1.2    STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

EtO, SO2, and PO (all 100 mol% concentration) are transported to the site in pressurized tanker rail cars and are loaded into the following storage vessels:



?    2 - 53,000-gallon pressurized bullet tanks for EtO;

?    1 - 8,000-gallon pressurized bullet tank for SO2; and

?    1 - 36,720-gallon pressurized bullet tank for PO.



Additionally, the site maintains several railcars on location for additional storage of EtO and PO in order to maintain an adequate supply of product for the processes.  Those railcars are unloaded to the vessels indicated above and are listed below:



?    17 - 20,000-gallon pressurized railcars for EtO; and

?    2 - 20,000-gallon pressurized railcars for PO.



EtO, SO2, and PO are piped under their own pressure to various locations throughout the facility.  Access to the storage tanks is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel, and authorized contractors.  The maximum amount of the subject chemicals that can be stored at the site are as follows:



?    EtO - 446,000 gallons;

?    SO2 - 8,000 gallons; and

?    PO  - 76,720 gallons.



1.3    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with OSHA, the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA), and recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.  All employees h

ave received on-the-job training and written testing regarding accidental release prevention.



1.4    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases from the covered processes.  Specifically, there have been no accidental releases that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



1.5    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility's emergency response program is based upon OSHA Standards.  Oxiteno has discussed this program with local emergency response agencies, including the Pasadena Fire Department and Pasadena Local Emergency Planning Committee.



1.6    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The facility was constructed in 2012 and is in compliance with OSHA Standards 1910 and 1926.  Subsequent processes and facility improvements will be in compliance with these standards.
